media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Events! Events Everywhere!
media:group.media:description:
by Lutz Huehnken
As we all know, naming things is one of the really hard problems in computer science. Maybe this is the reason the term “event” is used for what feels like at least twenty different concepts. It’s all too easy to get confused when people talk about Event Sourcing, Event Streaming, Event-Carried State Transfer, Notification Events, Domain Events, Fat Events, Event Storming and possibly yet other types of events. Serverless Functions - triggered by events, Apache Kafka users like to speak of events, as do those of the Axon framework - are they even meaning the same thing at all? And above all - why should I even bother with an Event-driven architecture, what are the benefits? Time for a proper clean-up. Let’s start with a clear and bounded definition of events, and from there explore the patterns of using events in micro- and macro-architecture, their benefits as well as challenges. After the talk, participants will know what questions to ask if someone suggests to go event-driven, and will be able to assess the applicability of different approaches to their architectural tasks.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - What You Say is What You Get: Hands-Free Coding in 2022

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - What You Say is What You Get: Hands-Free Coding in 2022
media:group.media:description:
by Wolfram Wingerath
Software for interpreting and synthesizing natural language is used by millions of people every day who use smart home assistants or simply prefer dictating over typing on their mobile phones. But while hands-free interfaces have found widespread adoption among consumers, IT professionals still mostly consider them gimmicks or do not consider them at all for the purpose of software development – unjustly so!
In this presentation, I will describe a zero-cost setup for hands-free coding that is extremely powerful and convenient to use. First, I will cover the basics of how to control your computer and navigate applications using just your voice (and eyes and facial expressions and more!), sharing best practices and common pitfalls. To jumpstart the learning process with a brief voice-coding session, I will then eat my own dog food by extending my voice command library via voice coding. Throughout the talk, I will share my personal experiences and explain how I tweaked my own setup to accommodate customized workflows. I will close the talk with how I use hands-free coding at my job and a list of pointers for getting started.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Form Validations Do Not Have To Suck. Introducing Vest!

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Form Validations Do Not Have To Suck. Introducing Vest!
media:group.media:description:
by Evyatar Alush
The web is what it is today much because of the form element, but even to this day forms are hard to write, maintain and validate properly. Forms are the interaction heavy parts of our apps, so this is where our users are most likely to experience bugs - and they often do.
In this session we'll learn together how to use Vest, a form validations framework inspired by unit testing libraries that makes it easy to validate even the most complex forms.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Meine! Deine! Keine! Verantwortung in agilen Teams

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Meine! Deine! Keine! Verantwortung in agilen Teams
media:group.media:description:
by Frank Düsterbeck
In dieser Session wird Verantwortung übernommen! Verantwortung dafür, intensive praktische Impulse zu geben. Wir nehmen Bezug auf die Theorie und klären, unter welchen Voraussetzungen Menschen Verantwortung annehmen oder ablehnen und ob Verantwortung teilbar ist. Wir ergründen, welche Verantwortung in agilen Teams liegt. Wir machen deutlich, welche Auswirkungen diese Erkenntnisse auf Führung hat. Mit anderen Worten: Wir schaffen Klarheit darüber, was geschehen muss, damit Verantwortung von allen Menschen angenommen werden kann.

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Building a decentralised pub/sub
media:group.media:description:
by Matthew Fontana
During the presentation Streamr’s co-founder and CEO Henri Pihkala will take a deep dive into building Streamr, a decentralized pub/sub network for real-time data. He will answer the question of how we can transport, share and monetize data in a secure and scalable manner without intermediaries. And he will elaborate on how new types of data pipelines and ecosystems support and accelerate the birth of the decentralized web or Web 3.0.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Reinforcement Learning - Selbstlernende Modelle entwickeln

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Reinforcement Learning - Selbstlernende Modelle entwickeln
media:group.media:description:
by Jörg Neumann
Bislang mussten AI Modelle oft mühsam trainiert werden um eine Intelligenz zu entwickeln. Zukünftig können sich Computer eigenständig trainieren und selbst nach Lösungswegen für komplexe Problemstellungen suchen. Dies eröffnet spannende, neue Einsatzgebiete. Jörg Neumann und Robin Müller geben einen Überblick über Reinforcement Learning und zeigen Ihnen, wie Sie die Technik sinnvoll entwickeln und einsetzen können.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - OpenTelemetry - ein offener Standard für den Durchblick in Anwendungslandschaften

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - OpenTelemetry - ein offener Standard für den Durchblick in Anwendungslandschaften
media:group.media:description:
by Dennis Kieselhorst
Um in verteilten Anwendungslandschaften den Überblick zu behalten, gibt es schon seit einiger Zeit unterschiedliche Ansätze um Daten wie Metriken, Traces und Logs zentralisiert zu analysieren. Die Uneinheitlichkeit machte es bislang aufwändig wirklich alle Komponenten einfach zu berücksichtigen. Im Jahr 2019 wurde unter dem Dach der Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) OpenTelemetry als herstellerneutrales, quelloffenes Ökosystem mit dem Ziel geschaffen die Erfassung und Übertragung von Telemetriedaten zu standardisieren.
In diesem Lightning Talk werden die Spezifikation und deren Bestandteile kurz vorgestellt. Es wird gezeigt, wie sie in Anwendungen integriert werden kann. Zuletzt wird auf die Interaktion mit Cloud-Infrastruktur eingegangen, da OpenTelemetry sich insbesondere auf cloud-native Anwendungen fokussiert.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - The power of mocking APIs

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - The power of mocking APIs
media:group.media:description:
by Shivani Gaba
Blocked because the API you depend on doesn’t exist yet or isn’t completely ready? Facing trouble to test various scenarios due to lack of control over third-party APIs? Struggling to verify failure cases like receiving an invalid response , 5XX errors and so on? Having flaky tests due to slow API responses? These are some very common problems we encounter. We cannot rely on slow APIs, which provide a very narrow range of responses. So how can we test effectively in such situations? Is there any feasible solution available? Fortunately, there is: mocking of APIs. In this session, I will explain how to stub APIs using Wiremock. With a real life example application, we’ll explore how to handle complicated scenarios and form testing strategies. Join this session to gain insights on how, when, and most importantly why we should stub APIs. Let’s find together how development and testing can benefit from mocks.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Going real time using Azure CosmosDB and React

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Going real time using Azure CosmosDB and React
media:group.media:description:
by Olena Borzenko
Traditionally, when building SPA applications, it feels a lot like we are looking at the moon. On the light side, we have the shiny and pretty UI, which everyone knows and loves. However, on the dark side, there is the complicated server-side logic behind the scenes we need to manage.
Luckily, there has been much progress towards making our lives as developers a bit easier. This is done by allowing us to concentrate on writing code, instead of causing us headaches from all aspects around hosting, deployment, and management.
In this demo-rich session, we are going to build a real-time stock monitoring system using a serverless React App backed by the power of various Azure features. You will learn how to process documents from Azure Cosmos DB Change Feed, and then broadcast this newly received data to our client, all by using out-of-the-box Azure Functions bindings for Cosmos DB and SignalR.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Composer Package Development - Wie es richtig gemacht wird

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Composer Package Development - Wie es richtig gemacht wird
media:group.media:description:
by Till Kobbe
Jeder PHP-Developer kennt und nutzt Composer Packages. Doch wie funktionieren diese Packages und wie kann ich meine eigenen Packages entwickeln?
In diesem Vortrag erkläre ich die allgemeine Vorgehensweise bei der Entwicklung eigener Composer-Packages und erläutere Besonderheiten und Best Practices im Zusammenhang mit dem Laravel-Framework. Ich werfe einen Blick auf bekannte Packages und erarbeite Learnings für den eigenen Entwicklungsprozess. Abschließend beantworte ich mit Hilfe von zwei Anwendungsbeispielen die Frage, wann und wie ich Code in Packages auslagern sollte.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Predictive preloads for ultimate web performance?

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Predictive preloads for ultimate web performance?
media:group.media:description:
by Erik Witt
The premise is very simple: loading resources that the user needs next before they are needed leads to a big gain in the performance of your web application. So why again isn't everyone doing that already? The reason is, that predicting what a user does next is much more complicated and doing it so you can make decisions in the browser during a live user session faces a lot of very interesting engineering and data science questions. In this talk we look at a predictive preloading system A/B tested with over 100 million users. We explore the machine learning models behind it based on hundreds of millions of user sessions, the achieved performance improvements, and the tradeoffs to consider.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Update your team to be more extreme

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Update your team to be more extreme
media:group.media:description:
by Jose Maria Valera Reales
Our profession is constantly evolving; therefore, it demands a non-stop learning process. Embracing the change is not optional in our software industry. We need to create spaces to get out of our comfort zone, so our cognitive brain can train and improve how to adapt to our surroundings, which are constantly transforming. A solution for this could be by integrating internal tech talks or katas which provides the team a great opportunity to have fun while learning and sharing knowledge between the team members.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Setting up a multi-node network with Substrate

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Setting up a multi-node network with Substrate
media:group.media:description:
by Krystian Gaus
While general-purpose smart contract platforms such as Ethereum are revolutionary, they bring several limitations and design constraints into play.
Substrate offers a flexible and modular alternative to these limitations. Rather than creating a smart contract on top of an existing blockchain, Substrate provides the tools to build an upgradeable special-purpose blockchain with the core application logic being an integral part of the blockchain runtime itself.
In this talk, we will briefly examine the idea of a heterogeneous multi-chain, and in the main part, we will set up a Substrate-based multi-node network.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Web UI Feuerwerk mit SVG und der Web Animation API

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Web UI Feuerwerk mit SVG und der Web Animation API
media:group.media:description:
by Jörg Neumann
Die Anforderungen an Web UIs steigen stetig. Doch all die schönen Design-Konzepte müssen auch umgesetzt werden. Dies stellt Entwickler vor einige Herausforderungen. Neben CSS bietet sich vor allem SVG an, wenn es darum geht grafisch komplexe Komponenten zu entwickeln. Jörg Neumann und Thomas Reinsch zeigen an vielen Beispielen, wie Sie Designvorgaben effektiv umsetzen und mit Hilfe von Animationen veredeln.

entry.title: code.talks 2022 - Machine Learning without the Data #federatedlearning

media:group.media:title: code.talks 2022 - Machine Learning without the Data #federatedlearning
media:group.media:description:
by Matthias Lau & Kai Wendlandt
Machine learning is a lot about data, but what if the data is somewhere else. What if you cannot centralize all the data or if this would not be a good idea. Privacy-preserving machine learning technologies enable us to train on data we will never see. This talk will introduce some basic concepts for privacy preserving machine learning and go through the core technology, e.g. Federated Learning, Differential Privacy, Homomorphic Encryption. We will look at all components of a working setup using the Flower framework.
